title: What are some hidden treasures of your city? - Quora

response.answer_text: In Toronto, Canada, start with the parks! The good ones are obvious, here are the non-obvious ones  Edwards Gardens at Lawrence Avenue and Leslie Street. Not easy to get to by car as it’s tucked away against a ravine system (which it links to so you can explore afterwards)  Rouge National Urban Park. Eventually it will be larger than Manhattan. At the extreme eastern edge of the city, it’s pretty much impossible to get to except by car. If you’re lucky, you will see wild deer. The park is untouched wilderness - the only area like it in all of Southern Ontario  Sherwood Park in North Toronto, It’s part of the much larger Don Valley Park system, but it’s one of the hardest to find and get to. The entrance with parking is nearly impossible to find and it’s a long way even from the nearest bus stop. Now some other attractions johnvince John Vince Foods - Toronto’s largest bulk food store. Found in a non-descript building in a light industrial neighbourhood, it has a massive selection of bulk food products plus an instore cafe. John Vince Foods is one of the largest bulk wholesalers in Toronto and buys from sellers all over North America through their stall at the Ontario Food Terminal. The store is close to the new Downsview Park subway station. Meanwhile, if you’re in the neighbourhood…  The Downsview Park Merchant’s Market Food Court. Open only on weekends, the food court is regularly picked as the best food court in the city. The Merchant’s Market is housed in an old military building on the park, which used to be an air base.  Osgoode Hall in downtown Toronto, next to Nathan Philips Square. One of the oldest buildings in the city and it’s best example of early 19th century architecture. It’s the home of the provinces top appeals court and Ontario’s legal regulator, the Law Society of Ontario. Guided tours are available, but the building is freely accessible if you behave yourself.  Kensington Market. Tucked away on side streets near College and Spadina, the neighbourhood has been home to independent businesses for a century. It has seen several waves of immigration and has resisted all attempts to open chains. It’s now dominated by small “hipster” establishments, but you can still get food there.  The Grange - Toronto’s oldest inhabited building. Now tucked in between towers and shopping malls, it’s being used as part of the nearby Art Gallery of Ontario.

So I have lived most of my life in Oxfordshire - England. I can guarantee that most of you have heard of it, Oxford is famed for being home to one of the most famous universities in the world and have some really beautiful architecture and museums. I thought long and hard as to what I would consider being a hidden treasure of Oxford; would it be the Pitt Rivers Museum, one of the many colleges or even the pub that J.R.R Tolkien and C.S. Lewis were known to frequent? Nope, none of these. One of my hidden treasures is this:  On first glance, you see an ordinary tree. Nothing remotely special at all. You may also notice the old building in the background. This tree sits in one of the cloisters in New College Oxford. It is a place I have spent many afternoons at, as my brother was one of the chorister (choir boys) for the College Choir. I have so many memories of afternoon parties around that tree and watching little boys play hide and seek through the arches. You’re probably wondering what makes this tree so special though, aside from personal memories that I would pick it out of all the gorgeous treasures in Oxford. Well maybe to some Harry Potter fans this tree might start to be a little more familiar?    Yes, it is the very same tree that Malfoy got turned into a ferret in the 4th Harry Potter Film - Goblet of Fire. Unlike most of the other filming spots in Oxford for Harry Potter, this location is not as well known as therefore attracts a lot fewer tourists. Why I would class it as the ultimate hidden gem of my city is because it has so much cultural significance and personal significance all the while being an iconic film location. If you are even in Oxford check it out - it is normally accessible to visitors for free! - Day 6 out of 365
